channel.title: For the love of christ please confirm I am right
channel.description:
So my science teacher's a bitch and pulls random volts and ohms out of her ass and gives us an assignment. Alright so the current drop on this parallel circuit. The battery is 1.5 Volts and the bulbs are 5 ohms each. The wires apparently have 0 resistance so we have an infinite number of amps to begin with. /sarcasm
|----------------------------------- | | | | | | Bat Bulb Bulb | | | | | | |------------------|----------------|
If I'm right, shouldn't the circuit lose current after the first branch?
1.5/5=.3 So all of the current should be gone..

item.title: For the love of christ please confirm I am right
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

simple voltage divider,

since they are in parallel , all of the circuit elements have the same voltage( think about gravitational potential)
as you did, 1.5/5=0.3, therefore each bulb will see a 0.3A current, thus the total current supplied by the battery is .6A, you can check this quickly by adding the bulbs which are in parallel to form a single equivalent bulb (resistor), thus we would now have:

btw this should not be hard, if you understand the basics

Read full topic
item.source: For the love of christ please confirm I am right
